tv.source-info-name: Pluto TV Space guide by TV

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Night Fire
programme.desc: The Northern Lights are more than just beautiful; they tell us about the make up of our planet, our sun, and may even be a signpost for the possibility of life on other planets.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hubble's Renaissance
programme.desc: Before we can reach space, we must first be able to see it. Hundreds of years ago, the simple telescope was used to give us a seemingly closer vantage. Today, we use the awe-inspiring, and super powerful, Hubble Space Telescope.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Virtual Universe
programme.desc: Our understanding of the cosmos is limited by the amount of time we have to see it. Fortunately, computer simulations can help us see how galaxies interact over millions of years, and even how dark matter structures the universe.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Fermi Paradox
programme.desc: The Fermi Paradox asks the ultimate question: Given a few reasonable assumptions about the chance of life arising elsewhere in the universe and the distance between the stars, why has an alien civilization not presented itself?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Landsat
programme.desc: Take a look at Landsat 8, the advanced planetary explorer with a 900 million dollar price tag! It is designed to peer across multiple wavelengths to reveal complex and ever-changing details that are undetectable by the human eye.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Brenham, Kansas
programme.desc: In Brenham, Kansas pieces of a large meteorite that fell thousands of years ago have been unearthed. Using advanced metal detection equipment Arnold and Notkin work tirelessly to find the meteorite pieces that have yet to be discovered.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: The Tucson Ring
programme.desc: In the 1850s a farmer came across a meteorite in Arizona; it's known as the "Tucson Ring" and now resides at the Smithsonian. Arnold and Notkin search for more pieces in an attempt to solve one of the biggest mysteries in the world of meteorite hunters.

programme.title: RISING TIDES
programme.desc: The next generation of Earth observation satellites are now in place maintaining the continuity of long-term climate data, in particular the planets rising temperatures and related ocean levels.

programme.title: The New Frontier: INCREASING ORBIT
programme.desc: The ISS is the workhorse of the international spacefaring community, but its days are numbered. R

programme.title: The New Frontier: Gravity
programme.desc: LISA pathfinder, has led the way for a space based gravity wave detector, what are gravity waves and why are they so hard to detect?

programme.title: The New Frontier: Shore To Shore
programme.desc: Our seafaring nature has translated well to the space age, seeking to sail out into the unknown in search of riches of one kind or another.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Planet X
programme.desc: The New Horizons mission continues deeper into space, it’s next target looming close.

programme.title: The New Frontier: OCEANS IN THE SKY
programme.desc: Juice and the Europa Clipper are two missions to our Solar System’s largest planet.

programme.title: MOON SHINE
programme.desc: The International drive to return to the Moon is gathering pace, this multi- nation effort is readying to return, stay and utilise the Lunar assets.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Juno, Cassini and Beyond
programme.desc: The Cassini space craft has completed its mission over Saturn, Juno has reached its target and has commenced its scientific observations of the giant planet Jupiter.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Interface
programme.desc: The Ionisphere, where the Earth interfaces with space, is little understood, it effects radio communications, GPS signals and satellites alike.

programme.title: The New Frontier: The Inner Worlds
programme.desc: They orbit between us and our Star, the inner worlds; hidden within the sun's glare often only visible at sunrise or sunset.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Superscopes
programme.desc: The human eye can only see visible light, a small spectrum of electromagnetic waves. Today, we have instruments that let us perceive all wavelengths.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Cosmic Rays
programme.desc: Cosmic rays can tell us much about the universe. They are not simply another form of light, but carriers of information about powerful and unseen processes at work thousands or even millions of light years away.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Windows to Other Worlds
programme.desc: As technology has advanced, we have been able to peer into distant reaches of space. From the first telescopes to high-tech satellites, these machines have been our windows to other worlds.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Fountain of Creation
programme.desc: Without the Sun's warmth and light, life as we know it would not exist. It is the powerhouse of our planet and provides the energy we need to survive.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Rocky Shores
programme.desc: The arid shores of other planets tell the stories of their past. What did they look like, and could they have ever supported life?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Silent Partner
programme.desc: Although we have put man on the moon, our silent partner still holds many mysteries. What haven't we seen? What haven't we discovered?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Borderland
programme.desc: Deserts and dunes, cliffs and canyons. Although Mars is certainly an alien wasteland, it is a planet with terrestrial formations remarkably similar to those found on Earth.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Mars: Red Dawn
programme.desc: Landing a spacecraft on Mars is no easy task given our limited knowledge of the planet. The difference between success and failure can rely on the most minute detail.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: The Giant Planets: Lords of Gravity
programme.desc: Gravity is one of the most basic and powerful forces shaping our universe. Discover its nature within our own solar system, from the smallest moons to the largest planets.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Outer Limits: Edge of the Solar System
programme.desc: For centuries, it was was thought that Saturn was the most distant planet in our Solar System. With the evolution of the telescope, we discovered the rest of our planets, both elusive and mysterious.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hidden Havens: Icy Moons
programme.desc: There are hundreds of moons in our solar system. Could one of them be a hidden haven that harbors alien life forms?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Icy Gems: Frozen Moons
programme.desc: In the far depths of space, out of reach of the Sun's warmth, water can only exist in a super solid state. Some small moons, in fact, are made entirely of ice. What stories do these Icy Gems have to tell about our solar system?

programme.title: RISING TIDES
programme.desc: The next generation of Earth observation satellites are now in place maintaining the continuity of long-term climate data, in particular the planets rising temperatures and related ocean levels.

programme.title: The New Frontier: INCREASING ORBIT
programme.desc: The ISS is the workhorse of the international spacefaring community, but its days are numbered. R

programme.title: The New Frontier: Gravity
programme.desc: LISA pathfinder, has led the way for a space based gravity wave detector, what are gravity waves and why are they so hard to detect?

programme.desc: Our seafaring nature has translated well to the space age, seeking to sail out into the unknown in search of riches of one kind or another.
